answers.answer: Hey,If you tested positive for antibodies, it means that you have autoimmune thyroid disease.  The fact that your tsh level is that high, means that you have hypothryoidism - and could have Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Your doc has most likely referred you to an endocrinologist.  What are your symptoms?  Sometimes you can have high antibodies and normal tsh as well.  Don't know much else to tell you other than make sure that you do some reading - here or elsewhere - and learn a little about that before you see your new doc.  Knowledge is power on the part of the patient.  Make yourself a file - get copies of all your test results - it helps sometimes to have these handy - if nothing else, but for yourself.  If you have any further questions, you are in a good place!  I will certainly help in any way that I can.  Keep posting!Peace,Charley

Thank you for your responses.  You have definetly helped ease my mind.I really didn't realize I had symptoms.  I am always tired, but I just attributed that to my weight.  Then of course my weight gain and inability to lose weight, but I just assumed I had a bad metabolism from years of yo-yo dieting.I am curious, my hips and back have been killing me for month's now.  Could this be related?I am so looking forward to feeling great!  I wouldn't say normal, because I thought what I was feeling was normal!!Again, I appreciate your help on this. I feel soooo much better!!

Hypo (whether caused by an autoimmune disorder or not) is treated with thyroid replacement (such as your Levothyroxine).  Your doctor (hopefully you are seeing an endocrinologist) will want to adjust your medications to bring you into normal range.  You dose of .88 every other day is quite conservative; possibly TOO conservative.If the Levoxyl isn't making the desired changes with a change in dosage your doctor will probably try you on another form of thyroid replacement medication.  Many of us have been through at least 2 or 3 brands or types before we find the magic one (then just try to pry it out of our hands!!!)  :-)

Glad I could help.  I don't know for sure but I do believe the bone pains can be related (often thyroid patients have other autoimmune problems like arthritis, fibromyalgia, etc.).Hey, you mentioned the weight gain - not fun is it?  Please get your glucose levels checked - *many* of us thyroid patients develop Type II diabetes.You will feel better!  I won't say "normal" because what really is "normal" but it will take a bit of time.  Be patient but be persistent with your endocrinologist.  Many of us have been through a few of them too before we found one who would treat us - not our lab results.Hang in there!

question: I have been taking Levoxyl for about 4 years now. My dose was slowly increasing, and my doctor most recently put me on .88 and 1 every other day.I went in for an exam with my primary doctor the other day, and she said that my thyroid was large.  She ordered my blood work, and my doctor called today with the results.  My antibodies were 11,000, and my TSH was 14.48.She has since referred me to a specialist.  I am so concerned, as I do not know what to expect.If anyone has an advise they could give me, it would be greatly appreciated.Thank you!!
title: Thyroid Blood Test Results
